    Chapters:

  • Chapter 2.04 - CITY MANAGER*
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Sections:


  • 2.04.010 - Office created.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The office of the city manager is created and established. The city manager shall be appointed by the city council and shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.020 - Residence requirement.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Residence in the Big Bear Valley (the Big Bear Valley being defined as the municipal water district's corporate limits) at the time of appointment of the city manager shall not be required as a condition of the appointment, but within one hundred eighty days after reporting for work, the city manager must become a resident of the Big Bear Valley.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.030 - Eligibility of council members.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    No member of the city council shall be eligible for appointment as city manager until one year has elapsed after such council member has ceased to be a member of the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.040 - Bond required.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager or acting city manager shall furnish a corporate surety bond to be approved by the city council in such sum as may be determined by the city council, and shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties imposed upon the city manager or acting city manager as prescribed in this chapter. Any premium for such bond shall be a proper charge against the city.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.050 - Acting city manager.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager, by filing a written notice with the city clerk, shall designate a qualified city employee to exercise the powers and perform the duties of city manager during his/her temporary absence or disability. In the event the city manager's absence or disability is expected to extend for a two-month period or greater, the city council shall appoint an acting city manager.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.060 - Compensation.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager shall receive such compensation as the city council shall from time to time determine. In addition, the city manager shall be reimbursed for all actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of his/her official duties.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.070 - Powers and duties.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager shall be the administrative head of the government of the city under the direction and control of the city council. The city manager shall be responsible for the effective and efficient administration of all the affairs of the city which are under his/her control pursuant to the city's charter. In addition to his/her general powers as administrative head, and not as a limitation thereon, it shall be his/her duty and he/she shall have the powers set forth in Sections 2.04.080 through 2.04.180 of this chapter.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.080 - Law enforcement duties.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to enforce all laws and ordinances of the city and to see that all franchises, contracts, permits and privileges granted by the city council are faithfully observed.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.090 - Authority over employees.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager, and he/she shall have the authority to control, order and give directions to all heads of departments and to subordinate officers and employees of the city under his/her jurisdiction through their department heads, except the department of water and power general manager.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.100 - Power of appointment and removal.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to, and he/she shall appoint, remove, promote and demote any and all officers and employees of the city, except the city attorney, city clerk, treasurer and department of water and power general manager.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.110 - Administrative reorganization of offices.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the city manager, upon informing the city council, to conduct studies and effect such administrative reorganization of offices, positions or units under his/her direction as may be indicated in the interest of efficient, effective and economical conduct of the city's business.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.120 - Ordinances.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager, and he/she shall recommend to the city council for adoption such measures and ordinances as he/she deems necessary.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.130 - Attendance at council meetings.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to attend all meetings of the city council, unless at his/her request he/she is excused there from by the mayor, individually, or the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.140 - Financial reports.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to keep the city council at all times fully advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.150 - Budget.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to prepare and submit the proposed annual budget and the proposed annual salary plan to the city council for its approval.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.160 - Expenditure control and purchasing.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to make reasonable inquiries into the affairs of the city and any department or division thereof, and any contract or the proper performance of any obligations of the city. Further, it shall be the duty of the city manager to investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the city government and in regard to the service maintained by public utilities in the city.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.170 - Supervision of building and property.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager and he/she shall exercise general supervision over all public buildings, public parks and all other public property which is under the control and jurisdiction of the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.180 - Additional duties.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city manager to perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as may be delegated to him/her from time to time by ordinance or resolution, or other official action of the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.190 - Council-manager relations.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city council and its members shall deal with the administrative services of the city only through the city manager, except for the purpose of inquiry, and neither the city council nor any member thereof shall give orders or instructions to any subordinates of the city manager. The city manager shall take his/her orders and instructions from the city council, and no individual council member shall give any orders or instructions to the city manager. The city council retains the sole power of being the policy making and legislative body for the city, and the duties and powers of the city manager are expressly confined to the administrative service of the city.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.200 - Departmental cooperation.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of all subordinate officers and the city clerk, city treasurer and city attorney to assist the city manager in administering the affairs of the city efficiently, economically and harmoniously.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.210 - Attendance at commission meetings.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager or authorized representatives may attend any and all meetings of the planning commission and any other commissions, boards or committees created by the city council, upon his/her own volition or upon direction of the city council. At such meetings which the city manager attends, he/she shall be heard by such commissions, boards or committees as to all matters upon which he/she wishes to address the members thereof, and he/she shall inform the members as to the status of any matter being considered by the city council, and he/she shall cooperate to the fullest extent with the members of all commissions, boards or committees appointed by the city council.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.220 - Removal of city manager.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The removal of the city manager shall be effected only by a majority vote of the whole city council as then constituted, convened in a regular or special council meeting, unless otherwise negotiated in a city manager's contract. The city council shall use its sole discretion in removing the city manager, and its action shall be final.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)
  • 2.04.230 - Agreements on employment.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as a limitation on the power or authority of the city council to enter into any supplemental agreement with the city manager delineating additional terms and conditions of employment not inconsistent with any provisions of this chapter.

    (Ord. 95-261 (part), 1995)

  • 2.08.010 - Meetings held without further notice.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at the hour of 3:00 p.m. for purposes of conducting a closed session, or such later time as set forth on an agenda posted for the city council meeting in accordance with the Ralph M. Brown Act, and 5:00 p.m. for purposes of conducting an open session, or such later time as set forth on an agenda posted in accordance with the Ralph M. Brown Act; unless the same shall be a legal holiday, in which event such regular meetings shall be held at the foregoing times on the next succeeding calendar day.

    (Ord. No. 2009-385, 1, 2-23-2009; Ord. 2004-336 1, 2004: Ord. 97-279 1, 1997: Ord. 95-265 1, 1995: Ord. 93-240 1, 1993: Ord. 93-230 1, 1993: Ord. 91-203 1, 1991: Ord. 4 1, 1980)

  • 2.08.020 - Meeting place.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The regular meeting of November 25, 1987, of the city council shall be held at 39707 Big Bear Boulevard, Big Bear Lake, and until further notice shall be the regular meeting place of the city council.

    (Ord. 87-152, 1987: Ord. 4 2, 1980)
  • Chapter 2.12 - PLANNING COMMISSION
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Sections:


  • 2.12.010 - CreationPurpose.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 3, Government Code Sections 65100, et seq., there is created a city planning commission for the city, which is known as the planning commission of the city of Big Bear Lake, and which may be referred to as the "planning commission." Its functions shall be as set forth in Section 65101 of the California Government Code, which functions are set forth as follows:

    1.

    It shall develop and maintain a general plan;

    2.

    It shall develop such specific plans as may be necessary or desirable;

    3.

    It shall periodically review the capital improvement program of the city;

    4.

    It shall perform other functions as the city council may order.

    B.

    All of the foregoing functions shall be performed in an advisory capacity to the city council, expect as specifically delegated to the planning commission by the city council.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 1, 1981)
  • 2.12.020 - MembershipAppointment.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    The planning commission consists of five members appointed by the mayor with approval of the city council.

    B.

    All members of the planning commission at the time of their appointment and during the term of their office shall be legally registered voters and residents of the city.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 91-194, 1991; Ord. 89-176 5, 1989: Ord. 88-161 18, 1988: Ord. 11 2, 1981)

  • 2.12.030 - Term of office.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    The term of office of each planning commissioner shall be for four years, ending June 30 of the applicable fourth year. The terms of two of the planning commissioners shall expire on June 30, 2003, and every fourth year thereafter; and the terms of three of the planning commissioners shall expire June 30, 2005, and every fourth year thereafter. Notwithstanding the foregoing, each planning commissioner shall continue to serve until his/her successor appointee takes office.

    B.

    Notwithstanding any provision in any ordinance heretofore enacted by the city council to the contrary, the terms of three planning commissioners who have assumed office in 2001 prior to the date of this amending ordinance shall expire June 30, 2005. The terms of the other incumbent planning commissioners shall be extended to and expire on June 30, 2003.

    (Ord. 2001-315 1, 2001: Ord. 99-295 1(part), 1999: Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 3, 1981)

  • 2.12.040 - MembershipRemoval.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Any appointed member may be removed by either of the following:

    A.

    The mayor, subject to approval of the city council; or

    B.

    A majority vote of the city council.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 4, 1981)
  • 2.12.050 - Vacancies.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    If a vacancy occurs otherwise than by expiration of a term, it shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired portion of the term.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 5, 1981)
  • 2.12.060 - Compensation.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The regular members of the planning commission shall receive such compensation as the city council may fix from time to time by resolution.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 91-202 1, 1991: Ord. 17, 1981: Ord. 11 9, 1981)
  • 2.12.070 - Adoption of rules.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The planning commission shall adopt rules for the transactions, resolutions, findings and determinations.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 6, 1981)
  • 2.12.080 - Code of ethics.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The individual members of the planning commission shall adhere to the code of ethics of the planning commission adopted by the city council on February 8, 1996 and as may be amended from time to time through adoption of a resolution. Failure to adhere to the code may be cause for removal from the planning commission pursuant to Section 2.12.040 of this chapter. The sole penalty for violation of the code of ethics shall be removal from the planning commission pursuant to Section 2.12.040 of this chapter.

    (Ord. 99-295 1(part), 1999: Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996)
  • 2.12.090 - Officers.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The planning commission shall elect a chair and vice-chair from among the appointed members and shall appoint a secretary who needs to be a member of the commission. Officers hold office for one year, or until their successors are elected.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 11 7, 1981)
  • 2.12.100 - Duties and procedures.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    The planning commission shall determine the order of business for the conduct of its meetings and shall meet in such regular sessions as its rules or procedures may provide. Special meetings may be called at any time by the chair or by three members of the commission. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The commission shall have all the powers and shall perform all the duties conferred and imposed upon city planning commissions by the applicable provisions of the Government Code of the state of California and, in addition, the commission shall:

    1.

    Prepare, adopt and maintain a long-range comprehensive master plan for the physical growth and development of the city and areas related directly to the city. The master plan shall reflect the future goals of the city after its adoption by the city council and shall represent the city's policy on matters of physical development. It shall guide the general location of future public facilities and improvements, and aid in the encouragement and regulation of private development;

    2.

    Prepare and adopt plans for the construction or clearance, rebuilding and redevelopment of those areas of the city suffering from blighted conditions;

    3.

    Serve as an advisory body to the city council on matters related to the city growth and development and on such other matters as may be requested by the city council;

    4.

    Promote public interest in planning and encourage citizen participation in the implementing of the master plan;

    5.

    Engage in a program of acquainting the public with citizen participation in the implementing of the master plan;

    6.

    The planning commission shall study and recommend on the following projects to the city council:

    a.

    Annexations;

    b.

    General plan amendments;

    c.

    Ordinances dealing with landscaping, land use, street name changes, zoning, development standards, subdivisions, off-street parking, building requirements and public facilities;

    d.

    Reversion to acreage;

    e.

    Street dedications and abandonments;

    f.

    Time-sharing applications;

    g.

    Zone changes.

    7.

    The planning commission shall approve, conditionally approve or deny the following projects:

    a.

    Large-scale housing projects;

    b.

    Major deviations;

    c.

    Public hearing site approvals;

    d.

    Tentative tract maps (five or more lots/units);

    e.

    Appeals of the planning department's decision on land use projects/issues.

    Notice of commission approval, conditional approval or denial on the projects listed in subsection (A)(7) of this section shall be sent to the members of the city council by the planning commission secretary within five working days of the decision. Commission action can be appealed by any interested party after a public hearing has been scheduled before the city council on the appeal, change or modification. Notice of the interested party's intent to appeal a decision of the planning commission must be filed within fifteen days of the planning commission's decision.

    B.

    Prior to approving projects, the planning commission shall be required to make the necessary finding as outlined in state, county and local laws or ordinances.

    C.

    The commission, by its secretary, shall keep and prepare minutes of all meetings the commission and shall forward copies thereof to each member of the council.

    D.

    The commission shall also determine reasonable rules for the attendance of its members, and shall notify the council when any member of the commission fails to abide by such rules.

    (Ord. 96-269 2(part), 1996: Ord. 92-208 1, 2, 1992; Ord. 83-76 1, 1983: Ord. 11 8, 1981)

  • Chapter 2.16 - PERSONNEL SYSTEM
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Sections:


  • 2.16.010 - Adoption of personnel system.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    In order to establish an equitable and uniform system for dealing with personnel matters, and to comply with applicable laws relating to the fair and equitable administration of the personnel process, the following personnel system is adopted.

    (Ord. 81-24 1, 1981)
  • 2.16.020 - Definitions.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The terms used to administer the personnel system shall be defined in the personnel rules.

    (Ord. 81-24 2, 1981)
  • 2.16.030 - Administration.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager shall administer the city personnel system and may delegate any of the powers and duties to a personnel director or may delegate the appointing authority granted by the city council to any other officer or employee of the city or may recommend that such powers and duties be performed under contract as provided in Section 2.16.130 of this chapter. The city manager or personnel director shall:

    A.

    Administer all the provisions of this chapter and of the personnel rules not specifically reserved to the city council;

    B.

    Prepare and recommend to the city council personnel rules and revisions and amendments to such rules;

    C.

    Prepare or cause to be prepared a position classification plan, including class specifications and revisions of the plan;

    D.

    Have the authority to discipline employees in accordance with this chapter and the personnel rules of the city;

    E.

    Provide for the publishing and posting of notices of tests for positions in the competitive service; the receiving of applications therefore; the conducting and grading of tests; the certification to the appointing power of a list of all persons eligible for appointment to the appropriate position in the competitive service; and performing any other duty that may be required to administer the personnel system.

    (Ord. 81-24 3, 1981)
  • 2.16.040 - Applicability.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all offices, positions and employments in the service of the city except:

    A.

    Elective officers;

    B.

    The city manager and any assistants to the city manager;

    C.

    Members of appointive boards, commissions and committees;

    D.

    All department heads;

    E.

    Persons engaged under contract to supply expert, professional, technical or any other services;

    F.

    Volunteer personnel, such as volunteer firemen;

    G.

    All council appointed city officers;

    H.

    Emergency employees who are hired to meet the immediate requirements of an emergency condition, such as an extraordinary fire, flood or earthquake which threatens life or property;

    I.

    Employees, other than those listed elsewhere in this section, who are not regularly employed in permanent positions;

    J.

    Any position primarily funded under a state or federal employment program;

    K.

    Big Bear Lake Fire Protection District employees.

    (Ord. 81-24 4, 1981)
  • 2.16.050 - Adoption and amendment of rules.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Personnel rules shall be adopted by resolution of the city council. The rules may establish regulations governing the personnel system, including:

    A.

    Preparation, installation, revision and maintenance of a position classification plan covering all positions in the competitive service, including employment standards and qualifications for each class;

    B.

    Appropriate announcement of the selection process and acceptance of applications for employment;

    C.

    Preparation and conduct of tests and the establishment and use of resulting employment lists containing names of persons eligible for appointment;

    D.

    Certification and appointment of persons from employment lists, and the making of provisional appointments;

    E.

    Establishment of probationary testing periods;

    F.

    Evaluation of employees during the probationary testing period;

    G.

    Transfer, promotion, demotion, reinstatement, disciplinary action and layoff of employees in the competitive service;

    H.

    Separation of employees from the city ser-vice;

    I.

    The establishment and maintenance of adequate personnel records for purposes of accounting and legal requirements;

    J.

    The establishment of any necessary appeal procedures.

    (Ord. 81-24 5, 1981)
  • 2.16.060 - Appointments.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Appointments to vacant positions in the competitive service shall be made in accordance with the personnel rules. Appointments and promotions shall be based on merit and fitness to be ascertained so far as practicable by competitive examination. Examinations may be used and conducted to aid in the selection of qualified employees and shall consist of selection techniques which will test fairly the qualifications of candidates such as achievement and aptitude tests, written tests, personal interview, performance tests, physical agility tests, evaluation of daily work performance, work samples or any combinations of these or other tests. The probationary period shall be considered an extension of the examination process. Physical and medical tests may be given as part of any examination.

    B.

    In any examination, the personnel director may include, in addition to competitive tests, a qualifying test or tests, and set of minimum standards therefore;

    C.

    Appointments shall be made by the city council, or by the officer in whom the power to make appointments is vested.

    (Ord. 81-24 6, 1981)
  • 2.16.070 - Probationary period.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    All regular appointments, including promotional appointments, shall be for a probationary period of not less than six months or longer as determined by the personnel rules. During the probationary period, the employee may be rejected at any time without the right of appeal or hearing.

    B.

    An employee rejected during the probationary period from a position to which he has been promoted shall be reinstated to a position in the class from which he was promoted unless he is discharged from the city service as provided in the personnel rules.

    C.

    An employee in the competitive service promoted or transferred to a position not included in the competitive service shall be reinstated to a position in the class from which he was promoted or transferred if action is taken to reject him, unless he is discharged in the manner provided in this chapter and the personnel rules for positions in the competitive service.

    (Ord. 81-24 7, 1981)
  • 2.16.080 - Status of present employees.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Any person holding a position included in the competitive service who, on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, has served continuously in such position, or in some other position in the competitive service, for a period equal to the probationary period prescribed in the rules for his class, shall assume regular status in the competitive service in the position held on such effective date without a qualifying test, and shall thereafter be subject in all respects to the provisions of this chapter and the personnel rules.

    B.

    Any other persons holding positions in the competitive service shall be regarded as probationers who are serving out the balance of their probationary periods as prescribed in the rules before obtaining regular status. The probationary period shall be computed from the date of appointment or employment.

    (Ord. 81-24 8, 1981)
  • 2.16.090 - Demotion, dismissal, reduction in pay, suspension.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city manager, personnel director or any designated appointing power shall have the right to demote, discharge, file letters of reprimand, reduce in pay or suspend any regular employee for cause.

    (Ord. 81-24 9, 1981)
  • 2.16.100 - Right of appeal.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Any employee in the competitive service shall have the right to appeal a disciplinary action, except in those instances where the right of appeal is specifically prohibited by this chapter or the rules adopted there under.

    B.

    All appeals shall be processed in accordance with the requirements and procedures as set forth in the personnel rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this chapter.

    (Ord. 81-24 10, 1981)
  • 2.16.110 - Layoff and reemployment.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Layoff and reemployment actions shall follow the process outlined in the personnel rules.

    (Ord. 81-24 11, 1981)
  • 2.16.120 - Political activity.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The political activities of city employees shall conform to pertinent provisions of state law and any local provision adopted pursuant to state law.

  • Chapter 2.24 - EMERGENCY SERVICES ORGANIZATION
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Sections:


  • 2.24.010 - Purpose of provisions.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The declared purposes of this chapter are to provide for the preparation and carrying out of plans for the protection of life and property within this city in the event of an emergency; the direction of the emergency organization; and the coordination of the emergency functions of this city with all other public agencies, corporations, organizations and affected private persons.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.020 - Emergency defined.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    As used in this chapter, "emergency" means the actual or threatened existence of conditions of disaster or of extreme peril to the safety of life and property within the city caused by such conditions as air pollution, fire, flood, storm, epidemic, riot or earthquake, or other conditions including conditions resulting from war or imminent threat of war, but other than conditions resulting from a labor controversy, which conditions are, or are likely to be, beyond the control of the services, personnel, equipment and facilities of this city, requiring the combined forces of other political subdivisions to combat.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.030 - Disaster councilCreated membership.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city disaster council is created and shall consist of the following:

    A.

    The mayor of the city, who shall be chairman of the disaster council;

    B.

    The mayor pro tem of the city, who shall be the vice-chairman of the disaster council;

    C.

    Such chiefs of emergency services as are provided for in a current emergency plan of this city, adopted pursuant to this chapter.

    (Ord. 93-232 7, 1993: Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.040 - Disaster councilPowers and duties.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It shall be the duty of the city disaster council, and it is hereby empowered, to develop and recommend for adoption by the city council, emergency and mutual aid plans and agreements, and such ordinances and resolutions, and rules and regulations as are necessary to implement such plans and agreements. The disaster council shall meet upon call of the chairman or, in his absence from the city or inability to call such a meeting, upon call of the vice chairman.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.050 - Director and assistant directorOffice created.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    There is created the office of director of emergency services. The city manager shall be the director of emergency services.

    B.

    There is created the office of assistant director of emergency services, who shall be the mayor.

    C.

    There is created the office of deputy director of emergency services, who shall be appointed by the director.

    (Ord. 93-232 8, 1993: Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.060 - Director and assistant directorPowers and duties.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    The director, and in the absence of the director, the assistant director, is empowered to:

    1.

    Request the city council to proclaim the existence or threatened existence of a "local emergency" if the city council is in session, or to issue such proclamation if the city council is not in session. Whenever a local emergency is proclaimed by the director, the city council shall take action to ratify the proclamation within seven days thereafter or the proclamation shall have no further force or effect;

    2.

    Recommend that the city manager or city council request the Governor to proclaim a "state of emergency" when, in the opinion of the director, the locally available resources are inadequate to cope with the emergency;

    3.

    Control and direct the effort of the emergency organization of this city for the accomplishment of the purposes of this chapter;

    4.

    Direct cooperation between and coordination of services and staff of the emergency organization of this city; and resolve questions of authority and responsibility that may arise between them;

    5.

    Represent this city in all dealings with public or private agencies on matters pertaining to emergencies as defined herein;

    6.

    In the event of the proclamation of a "local emergency" as herein provided, the proclamation of the "state of emergency" by the Governor or the Director of the State Office of Emergency Services, or the existence of a "state of war emergency," the director is hereby empowered:

    a.

    To make and issue rules and regulations on matters reasonably related to the protection of life and property as affected by such emergency; provided, however, such rules and regulations must be confirmed at the earliest practicable time by the city council;

    b.

    To obtain vital supplies, equipment and such other properties found lacking and needed for the protection of life and property, and to bind the city for the fair value thereof and, if required immediately, to commandeer the same for public use;

    c.

    To require emergency services of any city officer or employee and, in the event of the proclamation of a "state of emergency" in the city or the existence of a "state of war emergency," to command the aid of as many citizens of this city as he deems necessary in the execution of his duties; such persons shall be entitled to all privileges, benefits and immunities as are provided by state law for registered disaster service workers;

    d.

    To requisition necessary personnel or material of any city department or agency; and

    e.

    To execute all of his ordinary power as director of emergency services, all of the special powers conferred upon him by this chapter or by resolution or emergency plan pursuant hereto adopted by the city council, all powers conferred upon him by any statute, by any agreement approved by the city council, and by any other lawful authority.

    B.

    The director of emergency services shall designate the order of succession to that office, to take effect in the event the director, or assistant director, is unavailable to attend meetings and otherwise perform his duties during an emergency. Such orders of succession shall be approved by the city council.

    C.

    The deputy director of emergency services shall, under the supervision of the director and with the assistance of emergency service chiefs, develop emergency plans and manage the emergency programs of this city; and shall have such other powers and duties as may be assigned by the director.

    The deputy director of emergency services shall, prior to an emergency, be responsible for:

    1.

    Development and coordination of the emergency service planning for the city, which will provide for the utilization of all governmental entities, their resources and equipment; all commercial and industrial resources; all special groups, bodies and organizations as may be necessary for the support of emergency service operations;

    2.

    Development and coordination of such training programs and exercises as may be necessary for operational requirements;

    3.

    Development and coordination of programs designed to inform the public of measures for self-protection and emergency service activities;

    4.

    Liaison and coordination with federal, state, county and other city emergency service agencies, and with the appropriate elements of the armed forces;

    5.

    Recommendations to the city disaster council for consideration of all matters within the purview of the disaster council's responsibilities;

    6.

    Recommendations to the city council for consideration of matters of policy decision insofar as they relate to emergency services;

    7.

    Assigning duties and responsibilities to personnel of the office of emergency services.

    (Ord. 93-232 9, 1993; Ord. 82-72 1 (part), 1982)
  • 2.24.070 - Emergency organization members and disaster service workers.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Emergency Organization. All offices and employees of this city, together with those volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during an emergency, and all groups, organizations and persons who may by agreement or operation of law, including persons impressed into service under the provisions of subsection A6c of Section 2.24.060, be charged with duties incident to the protection of life and property in this city during such emergency, shall constitute the emergency organization of the city.

    B.

    Disaster Service Workers. All public and private volunteer agencies and members, i.e., disaster services, emergency medical services, search and rescue, and communication organizations, will register with the city emergency services as disaster service workers.

    (Ord. 82-72 1 (part), 1982)
  • 2.24.080 - Emergency planDevelopment responsibility.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    The city disaster council shall be responsible for the development of the city emergency plan, which plan shall provide for the effective mobilization of all of the resources of this city, both public and private, to meet any condition constituting a local emergency, state of emergency, or state of war emergency; and shall provide for the organization, powers and duties, services and staff of the emergency organization. Such plan shall take effect upon adoption by resolution of the city council.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)
  • 2.24.090 - ViolationPenalty.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    It is a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not to exceed five hundred dollars or by imprisonment for not to exceed six months, or both, for any person, during a state of war emergency, state of emergency or local emergency, or drill or exercise in preparation for such emergencies, to:

    A.

    Willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency organization in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter, or in the performance of duties, to include but not be limited to willful, deliberate interference with radio communications during practice drills or emergency between persons designated as agents of the city, paid or volunteer;

    B.

    Do any act forbidden by any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter, if such act is of such a nature as to give or be likely to give assistance to the enemy, or to imperil the lives or property of inhabitants of this city, or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof;

    C.

    Wear, carry or display, without authority, any means of identification specified by the emergency agency of the state or city.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)

  • 2.32.020 - Health officer definedArrest authority.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    A.

    Health Officer Defined. For the purposes of enforcement within the provisions of this chapter and Title 8 of this code, whenever the words "health officer" appear, they shall be deemed to mean and include the health officer of the city, or any duly appointed and authorized representative.

    B.

    Arrests. The health officer and every communicable disease investigator of tuberculosis of the city health department, who has the duty to enforce a statute or ordinance relating to communicable diseases of tuberculosis, may arrest a person for violation of such statute or ordinance as provided in Section 836.5 of the Penal Code. The authority conferred by this section shall not make such officers safety members of the city retirement system.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)

Such rules and regulations shall include and be in accord with the provisions of this code and all other applicable ordinances, statutes and recognized public health and safety practices.

    (Ord. 82-72 1(part), 1982)

  • Chapter 2.52 - PREVAILING WAGES
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Sections:


  • 2.52.010 - Prevailing wages required.
    • Share Link
    • Print
    • Download (docx)
    • Email
    • Compare

    Except on locally funded public works projects of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or less when the project is for construction work, or fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) or less when the project is for alteration, demolition, repair or maintenance work, all contractors performing work on a city public works projects shall be subject to California prevailing wage law, codified at California Labor Code Section 1720 et seq., as it may be amended from time to time. The only limitation on this requirement shall be in the event federal funding requirements supersede state prevailing wage laws.

    (Ord. No. 2014-435, 1, 10-27-2014)
